history.content:
Current freshman, in both 61B and 70.

70 has definitely been the more challenging one for me- I was in pretty rough shape at the beginning of the semester when we were doing graphs and all the other crazy discrete math stuff. I was able to do quite well on the first and second midterms and I attribute it to the following:

- Reading the notes early. While lectures were on Tuesday and Thursday, I read the corresponding notes on Monday and Wednesday morning. This gave me plenty of time to sit and brood over the concepts and try to understand them, and if I didn't...

- Going to office hours/HW parties regularly. Yeah the notes are dense. There's a lot of stuff that can fly over our heads. It's important to get that cleared up for yourself ASAP because other topics can build off of it. No better way to do that than having someone who knows their stuff help you go through it (thanks TAs!)

- Starting the problem set early, and attempting some problems alone. The traditional advice of doing HW in groups works great but sometimes you or I will "get carried" by group members who come up with answers first. It's worth spending an hour or two seeing if you can grasp a couple of the easier problems before putting your head together with your friends.

This let me keep pace with the course, so when exam time rolled around I was able to devote a couple of days to pure concept reinforcement with problems instead of scrambling to learn stuff that is on the test for the first time.

Hope this helps! 

–––––––––––––––––-

Hey – I'm also a current freshman; I took 70 with 61A last semester (and somehow did significantly better in 70 than 61A – maybe I'm in the wrong major lol). 

You say you didn't do too well in Math 1B, but that isn't necessarily indicative of how well you'll do in 70. 70 is far from a plug-and-chug math class; it takes a considerable amount of time for the material to sink in and for you to understand it. I echo the student above's sentiment – 70 is not a class that you can cram the night before an exam.

My personal strategy for 70 was to meet weekly with my homework group to work on the problems, usually on the Monday or Tuesday (with psets due Friday). We'd always first attempt the problems on our own, and if any of us were stuck/unconvinced of our answers, the others would do their best to explain until we were all convinced. The discussion that we had each week was vital as it helped me understand the concepts of the week when explained by my peers. However, when it came to exam preparation, I did this alone. Make sure you attempt your homework on your own first and that you write your solutions alone, otherwise it'll most likely bite you when it comes exam time. For exam prep, I just did as many past midterms as I could. I will admit, sometimes I peeked at the solutions, but the more and more I worked on concepts the less I had to do that.

I did have quite a bit of discrete and probability experience coming in, so YMMV. But if you're willing to put in major work, as you've stated, it is definitely possible to do well in the class. Good luck :)

------

If you don't feel that comfortable with math, I would strongly suggest taking EE16A/16B before CS70, or courses in the math department, to build more mathematical maturity beforehand.

children.subject: Different anon here. IMO, 61B (currently taking it) is slightly easier/more straightforward than 61A. But ofc, don't take it easy. I would generally give the same tips as above of taking the time to understand the concepts and doing problems on your own. Make sure to know the data structures, algorithms, and runtimes inside and out. Don't let yourself be carried on groupwork. Do a lot of practice problems, and think about hypothetical questions like what happens if you insert certain inputs into a data structure in a certain way, e.t.c.

Different Anon as well. Didn't take 61A, but 61B was relatively straightforward, but pretty time-consuming. Make sure to watch the lectures as they come out and do all the homework and labs a couple days early - they weren't that hard but doing them under pressure isn't good. For projects, you want to start early and talk through the concepts with other people. Try to find the best (theoretical) solutions to the problems rather than hacking through them and talk algorithms over with other people (ideally older people who've already taken it). Counterintuitively, I realized that I should have spent less time working on projects, because I would spend hours working on getting the last point or two (worth almost nothing in the overall grade) at the expense of studying for midterms, and as a result I only got an A-. Whereas CS70 has one super hard p-set per week, 61B is a deluge of time-consuming but relatively easy assignments, so as long as you keep on top of it and study hard for the midterms you should do fine.

Oh, and GO TO OFFICE HOURS. Especially the prof's OH. I learned this later in my student career, but most people only go to OH for debugging help, so if you go to the prof's OH or OH far away from project due dates, you can get a lot of conceptual knowledge and individualized attention.
Thanks a lot. Do you have any feedback for 61B?

Thanks to everyone who has replied so far and given feedback. Can someone else shed more light on this?

The more people who've gotten As on these classes in the past reply, the more helpful this will be!

history.content:
I'm a freshman and I took 61A last semester. It didn't go too well. I need an A- in both 61B and 70 to declare CS as my major, so can some people who've achieved an A on each class share how they went about doing these courses? What was your approach? What were the resources that helped you the most? What were techniques that gave you an edge? Are there any books or websites you recommend?


I've heard that for CS70, you need to go in with a positive mindset about Math. How can I hone this, considering that I took 1B last semester and didn't do too well on it? In general, I consider myself very average at Berkeley but I'm determined I can do this because it *is* possible to do very well in these classes and people do manage to pull it off. I look upto everyone here and I seek your guidance and any words of motivation are welcome. This means everything to me.
history.subject: Success in CS70 and 61B
